contextId.information: This can be written in modern measurements. AT: "a tenth of an ephah (which is about 2 liters)" or "2 liters " (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
A homer is a unit of volume equal to about 220 liters. AT: "2,200 liters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
An ephah is a unit of volume equal to about 22 liters. AT: "about 2 liters" or "two liters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
An ephah is a unit of volume equal to about 22 liters. AT: "4 liters" or "four and a half liters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
You may convert this to a modern measure. AT: "six and one half liters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])

"One-fourth" means one part out of four equal parts. This can be written in modern measurements. AT: "a liter" or "one-fourth of a hin (which is almost 1 liter)" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])

"Three tenths" means three parts out of ten equal parts. This can be written in modern measurements. AT:  "six liters" or "three tenths of an ephah (which is about six liters)" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
